They are going to last for $$$n$$$ days.During the holidays, Monocarp wants to try all of these activitiesexactly oncewith his friends:go skiing;watch a movie in a cinema;play board games.Monocarp knows that, on the $$$i$$$-th day, exactly $$$a_i$$$ friends will join him for skiing, $$$b_i$$$ friends will join him for a movie and $$$c_i$$$ friends will join him for board games.Monocarp also knows that he can't try more than one activity in a single day.Thus, he asks you to help him choose threedistinctdays $$$x, y, z$$$ in such a way that the total number of friends to join him for the activities ($$$a_x + b_y + c_z$$$) is maximized.InputThe first line contains a single integer $$$t$$$ ($$$1 \\le t \\le 10^4$$$) — the number of testcases.The first line of each testcase contains a number of friends that will join Monocarp for skiing on the $$$i$$$-th day.The third line contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$b_1, b_2, \\dots, b_n$$$ ($$$1 \\le b_i \\le 10^8$$$) — the number of friends You are given $n$ days. Each day, a certain number of people will join for skiing ($a_i$), a movie ($b_i$), and board games ($c_i$).  

You need to choose three distinct days ($x$, $y$, $z$) to do each activity once.  

Find the maximum total number of people who can join you across these three days ($a_x + b_y + c_z$). 

**Input:**

* $t$: The number of test cases.
* For each test case:
    * $n$: The number of days.
    * $a_1, a_2, ..., a_n$: The number of people joining for skiing each day.
    * $b_1, b_2, ..., b_n$: The number of people joining for a movie each day.
    * $c_1, c_2, ..., c_n$: The number of people joining for board games each day.

**Output:**

* For each test case, print the maximum total number of people who can join you.

You are given three lists of numbers representing the number of friends who want to do each of three activities on each of several days.  Find three different days such that the total number of friends joining for any combination of the three activities on those days is as large as possible.
